content.body: Returning a copy would be pretty useless in most cases when I think about it. That way you wouldn't ever be able to use find to modify an entry in the original array.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Returning a copy would be pretty useless in most cases when I think about it. That way you wouldn't ever be able to use find to modify an entry in the original array.

content.body:
> <@sideshowbarker:mozilla.org> in the code in that issue description, I‚Äôd have expected `const newCopy = { ...foundBananas }` does a shallow copy ¬†‚Äî and so, that `newCopy.quantity = 30` would also change the `quantity` property in `foundBananas`

`const newCopy = { ...foundBananas }` indeed does a shallow copy. The code is practically the same as `const newCopy = { name: foundBananas.name, quantity: foundBananas.quantity, }`. You can see in the latter case where changing the value would not change the original.

content.body:
> <@sideshowbarker:mozilla.org> What‚Äôs the distinction between a list and sequence? Is that distinction clear in most languages, or is it more distinct in C#?

think of a Sequence as any abstract iterable, while a List has a defined memory layout
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @sideshowbarker:mozilla.org

Is there anything different about lists than sequences which makes it better on lists?

What‚Äôs the distinction between a list and sequence? Is that distinction clear in most languages, or is it more distinct in C#?

think of a Sequence as any abstract iterable, while a List has a defined memory layout

content.body: That would seem to suggest that a List is a subclass of an (abstract) Sequence ‚Äî but the _‚ÄúIs there anything different about lists than sequences which makes it better on lists?‚Äù_ language that Eric Lippert uses in https://ericlippert.com/2009/05/18/foreach-vs-foreach/ seems to imply that they‚Äôre somehow two more-distinct things (in C#, I guess). But maybe I‚Äôm reading too much into it.
content.formatted_body: That would seem to suggest that a List is a subclass of an (abstract) Sequence ‚Äî but the ‚ÄúIs there anything different about lists than sequences which makes it better on lists?‚Äù language that Eric Lippert uses in https://ericlippert.com/2009/05/18/foreach-vs-foreach/ seems to imply that they‚Äôre somehow two more-distinct things (in C#, I guess). But maybe I‚Äôm reading too much into it.

But maybe I‚Äôm reading too much into it.

That would seem to suggest that a List is a subclass of an (abstract) Sequence ‚Äî but the ‚ÄúIs there anything different about lists than sequences which makes it better on lists?‚Äù language that Eric Lippert uses in https://ericlippert.com/2009/05/18/foreach-vs-foreach/ seems to imply that they‚Äôre somehow two more-distinct things (in C#, I guess). But maybe I‚Äôm reading too much into it.

content.body: When I see ‚Äúsequence‚Äù for me what comes to mind is C++, where there‚Äôs no Sequence as such in the language ‚Äî nothing formally called that ‚Äî but just the term ‚Äúsequence‚Äù is used in C++ documentation to distinguish the `vector`/`array`/`list` containers from the associative containers.
content.formatted_body: When I see ‚Äúsequence‚Äù for me what comes to mind is C++, where there‚Äôs no Sequence as such in the language ‚Äî nothing formally called that ‚Äî but just the term ‚Äúsequence‚Äù is used in C++ documentation to distinguish the vector/array/list containers from the associative containers.

content.body: And whereas in documentation for Java and Python (the main other languages I‚Äôm familiar with), there‚Äôs no set of things in the language that are typically referred to as ‚Äúsequence‚Äù things.

content.body: so the question is, if i omit the second `end` argument, do you think of it like if you gave an explicit `end` argument of the current last index of the TA (i.e. fixed-length), or do you think of it like you're creating a new TA of the same underlying buffer with no set end (i.e. length-tracking)?
